description: USDA Plant Hardiness Zone Index - Primary lookup key for agricultural intelligence
structure_note: USDA zone is the PRIMARY KEY. All geographic lookups resolve to USDA zone first, then drill down.
weather_foundation: USDA zones are weather-based (30-year average minimum winter temperatures). This provides the foundational link to harvest window and peak timing predictions (R pillar in SHARE framework).

why_zones_predict_timing.frost_dates: USDA zone determines last spring frost and first fall frost → defines growing season length
why_zones_predict_timing.gdd_accumulation: Zone temperature patterns determine GDD accumulation rate → predicts days to maturity
why_zones_predict_timing.harvest_windows: Zone-based growing season = when crops CAN be harvested in that geography
why_zones_predict_timing.peak_timing: GDD models + zone-specific temperature patterns = peak quality window predictions

example.zone_8: 10-20°F minimum → Spring frost to ~April, Fall frost ~October → 9-month season → Tomatoes ONLY spring+fall
example.zone_10: 30-40°F minimum → Rare/no frost → 12-month season → Tomatoes Oct-Jun year-round
example.insight: Same cultivar, different zone = different harvest timing. Zone IS the timing.

integration_with_share.R_pillar_connection: USDA zone provides the weather foundation for Ripen (R) pillar predictions

how_it_works.step1: USDA zone → Average frost dates (last spring, first fall)
how_it_works.step2: Frost dates → Growing season length in days
how_it_works.step3: Zone temperature patterns → Expected GDD accumulation rate
how_it_works.step4: GDD accumulation + cultivar requirements → Days to harvest
how_it_works.step5: Days to harvest + optimal timing window → Peak quality prediction

example_tomato_cherokee_purple.insight: Same cultivar, same GDD requirement, but different ZONES = different accumulation rates = different timing = different harvest windows

why_this_matters: USDA zone is OBJECTIVE (30-year weather data, not opinion)
Zone → GDD rates are PREDICTABLE (physics-based, not guesswork)
Harvest windows are VERIFIABLE (can measure actual vs predicted)
Quality timing is CALCULABLE (peak = optimal GDD within harvest window)
This makes Fielder's R pillar predictions DEFENSIBLE and SCIENTIFIC

lookupLogic.description: How to use USDA zones as primary key
steps: 1. GPS coordinates → USDA zone lookup (via USDA zone map API or database)
2. USDA zone → Harvest timing patterns (from this file)
3. USDA zone → Fielder growing regions in that zone
4. Fielder region → Specific soil/climate for SHARE predictions
5. Cross-reference state + zone for state-specific cultivar recommendations

example.step3: Zone 10a in FL → Fielder regions: southwest_fl, everglades_ag_area
example.step4: southwest_fl → Sandy loam soil, high drainage
example.step5: FL + Zone 10 → Tomatoes Oct-Jun, strawberries Nov-Apr
